ALLEGATION:
Confidential information regarding multiple individuals, many foster children,
serviced by the agency was breached.
INVESTIGATION:
On 5/4/2022 I reviewed the complaint document which was in the form of a letter to
the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS)-Contract
Administrator X, from Home for Black Children’s (HBC) Chief Administrator (CA) 1
date 4/28/2022. The letter advised DHHS-Contract Administrator X of a recent data
security event that may affect the security of personal information related to
Michigan residents subject to HBC’s contract with the state. This letter reported the
following information:
 Supplement information with new significant facts may be provided later.
 HBC through a third- party document review vendor, completed a
comprehensive programmatic and manual review of the at-risk files and
folders. HBC determined personal information related to 384 individuals,
largely minor children, who received services from HBC pursuant to the
contract with MDHHS may have been accessible. Out of the 384 individuals,
103 individuals required notice under Michigan state law as information that
constitutes person information, namely social security numbers under MCLA.
445.63(r) was identified as at-risk.
 Out of the 384, 117 individuals residing in Michigan were identified as having
information impacted that is not protected by Michigan state law, including
3

date of birth, Person ID, medical information, and health insurance
information. HBC is not a covered entity under the Health Insurance
Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA), as it is not a health care provider,
and it does not transmit health information in electronic form in connection
with covered tractions. Additionally, Michigan state law does not protect
dates of birth, Person IDs, medical information, or health insurance
information. Unless directed otherwise, HBC does not intend to provide
written notice to the 117 known Michigan residents whose only impacted data
elements are date of birth, Person ID, medical information, and /or health
insurance information.
 Of the total population of individuals associated with the State, there are 164
individuals for whom notice may be required, but whom HBC does not have
sufficient address information to make this determination. To the extent that
all of these individuals reside in Michigan, as HBC expect is the case, notice
is not required under state law as these individuals have only the following
data element impacted, which are not protected by Michigan state law: date
of birth, Person ID, medical information, and/or health insurance information.
HBC could securely provide a list of individuals associated for the State. At a
minimum HBC would need confirmation from the State that these are
residents of Michigan.
 Before HBC can provide notice to those individuals requiring notice under
Michigan state law, HBC was reviewing its internal records to confirm the
identities of the potentially affected individuals and locating address
information needed to notify them. For certain individuals who received
services pursuant to the MDHHS contract, HBC no longer maintained active
records. For those record HBC would need the State to provide address
information in order for HBC to mail notification letters. HBC had identified
172 individuals associated with the State for whom they could not locate an
address. HBC reported they could securely send a file of those identified
individuals to the State; and asked by what method did the State want to
receive that information and assist in providing the missing addresses.
 In the interim HBC would continue preparing to provide written notifications to
individuals by way of letter (a sample draft letter was reported to be attached,
that sample letter was not included with the complaint document I received)
For children impacted, HBC indicated a similar version of that letter would be
used and addressed to the parent or guardian of any minor child. Additionally,
credit monitoring would be offered, to the extent a social security number was
identified as impacted.
On 5/5/2022, 6/1/2022 and 6/15/2022 I interviewed Chief Administratator(CA) 1 related
to this complaint. CA 1 also provided clarification information related to the complaint
via email on other dates as reported in the methodology section of this report. CA 1
reported that on 7/15/2021 HBC had “Foreign Actors” to break into their techology
system. The Foreign Actors stole all of their files and held them for ransom. HBC
discovered there was a problem after staff tried to turn on computers to access the
agency’s system, and could not do so. CA 1 said they contacted their IT(Information
4

Techology) Department/Provider; IT Person 2. IT Person 2 advised them, HBC’s server
had been hacked.
CA 1 reported the server that was hacked was their old system. She said, they were in
the process of converting to a new server and “most of all that was on the old system
was on the new server”. CA 1 reported HBC worked with their insurance company, by
way of a “Threat Management Company”(TMC) hired to perform a forensic review of the
systems/files. She said the system’s lock out happened on a Friday; and due to HBC
having the new server, which the Foreign Actors did not realize, HBC was able to be
back up and running by Tuesday of the next week. She reported at that point they did
not know what was missing or touched related to the breach. She reported the server
data went back years, to 2013.
CA 1 reported from the time of the breach, lock out, the TMC negiotated back and forth
with the Foreign Actors. HBC paid the $10,000-$12,000 ransom and it took about two
weeks to get the key(code) so as to allow HBC back into their system. The TMC had to
go through each file to let HBC know what the Foreign Actors may have seen or
touched. The TMC reported HBC should air on the safe size, they should assume all the
files may have been exposed. It took the TMC months to get through the 384 possible
exposures. The TMC also provided intensive server monitoring for the first three
months. The server monitoring is now through HBC’s IT Provider.
CA 1 reported there being 14 names, some are foster children, some are staff( the
exact number for each was not reported by CA 1) that they could not find addresses
for. She was unable to provide me an exact number of foster or adoptive children or
families the breach related to. She reported the legal analysis of who requires notice of
the incident under Michigan law is still underway, as they continue working to collect
missing address information. She reported that based on the information gathered to
date, there were 65 individuals known to be associated with MDHHS that were
impacted by this incident and required notice under Michigan’s data breach notification
law.
I advised CA 1 that based on their 4/28/2022, and 1/7/2022 letter to MDHHS(which
HBC provided to me on 5/5/2022), HBC’s reporting of the incident to MDHHS did not
appear timely with respect to the” Loss or Compromise of Data” section HBC’s
contracts. I asked her for clarification, as to why she believes it was timely. CA 1
reported HBC’s attorney reviewed the contract to assure that reporting deadlines were
compliant. She repeated much of what she previously reported about HBC working with
third-party forensic specialists after learning of the incident. The purpose was to
investigate the potential incident and secure their systems; and for the team to conduct
an extensive programmatic and manual review of the potentially impacted data. She
reported while the investigation did not reveal any evidence that data were stolen from
the environment during the attack, the Foreign Actors may have viewed certain files on
HBC’s systems. She reported the third-party data review process was completed on
January 5, 2022. Upon receipt of the results of the third-party review, HBC reviewed the
data file to determine whether any MDHHS data was potentially impacted. She reported
5

that until they had an understanding of what data was impacted from the results of the
third-party review, they were unable to determine whether any data associated with
MDHHS individuals was impacted. On January 7, 2022, as part of HBC’s review of the
third-party data review results, they first determined that personal information related to
certain minor children who received services from HBC pursuant to the contract with
MDHHS may have been accessible. They provided preliminary notice to the department
via MDHHS-Contract Administrator X that same day on January 7, 2022. CA1 reported
the attorney used the “Loss or Compromise of Data” section of the contracts to make
the determination that their reporting of the breach was timely. She reported all
information she provided in letters to MDHHS or email proof to me is information,
advisement, or wording directly from their attorney.
CA 1 provided the following statement about the timeframe they used for reporting the
incident:
 “We identified the following provision (Section 4.31(e)) in the contract between
HBC and MDHHS: “Loss or Compromise of Data: In the event of any act, error,
or omission, negligence, misconduct, or a breach on the part of Contractor that
compromises or is suspected to compromise the security, confidentiality, or
integrity of State Data or the physical, technical, administrative, or organizational
safeguards put in place by Contractor that relate to the protection of the security,
confidentiality, or integrity of State Data, contractor must, as applicable: Notify
MDHHS as soon as practicable but no later than 24 hours of becoming aware of
such an occurrence.”
 That while HBC identified the suspicious activity in July 2021, HBC was not able
to confirm if the incident impacted any MDHHS data until it conducted a thorough
review of the data that was identified by the investigation as potentially
accessed. Put another way, until the third-party data review was complete, and
HBC could review the output of that third-party review, HBC did not know if any
state data was lost or compromised and, thus, could not confirm if the contract
provision was triggered. HBC promptly reviewed the results of the third-party
data review and determined on January 7, 2022, that data affiliated with MDHHS
services and the contract between MDHHS and HBC was impacted. HBC
notified MDHHS on January 7, 2022, within 24 hours of determining that
MDHHS-related data was impacted
On 5/13/2022 I interviewed HBC’s IT Provider, IT Person 2. IT Person 2 reported he is
an HBC subcontractor, and the agency’s IT person. He affirmed CA 1’s reporting that
HBC had a system’s break/hack, and information was held for ransom. He reported the
insurance company assumed nothing was taken. That the entity just locked the system
down, so it could not be accessed; and the actor(s) could conduct the ransom.
IT Person 2 reported HBC had a 2008 software server system that used a dumb
terminal to connect to the server. He said the agency was completing a 2016 upgrade
when the breach happened. He said that was in June or July of 2021. IT Person 2
reported the 2008 system had firewall/ security system protection, but the protection in
the 2016 system has greater protection. With the upgrade they put in a 90-day
6

password expiration; and tighter security at the firewall to reduce remote access (like
from home) without a two-factor identification. He said Microsoft has lots of defaults and
they changed somethings. They gave all staff new remote log in access. He reported
when the system attack happened, the staff could not work for about one to two weeks;
because they had to get, the 2016 server online; new security passwords for staff; and
transfer everything from the old server system to the 2016 system. He reported the HBC
server did not connect to the State’s system. Staff’s connection to the State’s system
was via a web browser and a two-factor identification.
IT Person 2 reported the agency’s server contained the agency’s word processing
documents, information from the State, such as memos. IT Person 2 reported when
they did a deep dive assessment, it was more like memos related to foster
care/adoption, but “no personal information that could be used to harm someone. The
word processing did not have children’s or foster home/adoptive home names or
anyone’s personal information.” He was not sure whether any children were affected by
the breach. He acknowledged he was not sure what would have been contained in all
those emails or word documents. He reported of all the documents (emails, word
documents, PDFs) the insurance company (TMC) did not find anything to show a
breach of information requiring a third-party notification. He reported all HBC’s
information was received back from the hackers. He reported per the insurance
company full social security numbers, full ID numbers or case numbers were not there
that associated with MDHHS. He said the agency should have a Final Analysis Report
of the incident from the insurance company. IT Person 2 reported he had not seen, nor
was he aware of HBC’s contract requirements related to reporting information to
MDHHS related to data breaches. He reported the agency may have notified the
department in July 2021. He connected that with HBC staff being unable to work for that
one-to two-week period.
Reviewed:
 The 4/28/2022 letter from HBC to MDHSS-Contract Administrator X-the basis for
this complaint, as reported earlier in this report.
 A copy of a 1/7/2022 letter from HBC’s CA 1 to MDHHS- Contract Administrator
X, regarding preliminary notice of the data event. The letter indicated that: On or
about 7/15/2021 HBC became aware of unusual activity related to certain files on
their computer systems when they discovered certain files were encrypted with
ransomware (“The Incident”). Additionally, that working with counsel and a third-
party forensic investigation firm HBC immediately launched an investigation into
the nature, and scope of the unusual activity. The forensic investigation
determined certain information was potentially accessible as a result of the
incident. While the investigation did not reveal evidence of data staging or data
exfiltration/theft, it determined that certain files and folders may have been
viewed or accessed by the unauthorized actor. Also as reported elsewhere in
this report, this letter indicated a third-party document review commenced and
was completed. The results were provided to HBC on 1/5/2022; and on 1/7/2022
HBC determined that personal information related to certain minor children who
received services from HBC, pursuant the contract HBC has with MDHHS, may
7

have been accessible. This letter indicated HBC would be providing written
notification to all affected individuals.
 HBC’s Foster Care and Adoption Contract- with specific notice of:
 Section 4.31, e. titled State Data under subsection, “Loss or Compromise
of Data”, that indicated “In the event of any act, error, or omission,
negligence, misconduct, or a breach on the part of Contractor that
compromises or is suspected to compromise the security, confidentiality,
or integrity of State Data or the physical, technical, administrative, or
organizational safeguards put in place by Contractor that relate to the
protection of the security, confidentiality, or integrity of State Data,
Contractor must, as applicable:
 1)Notify MDHHS as soon as practicable but no later than 24
hours of becoming aware of such an occurrence.”
 4.33, a. Data Privacy and Information Security, that indicated the
contractor is responsible for establishing and maintaining a data privacy
and information security program, including physical, technical,
administrative, and organizational safeguards, that is designed to·
 1)Ensure the security and confidentiality of the State Data;
 2) Protect against any anticipated threats or hazards to the security
or integrity of the State Data;
 3)Protect against unauthorized disclosure, access to, or use· of the
State Data;
 5) Ensure that all employees, agents, and subcontractors of
Contractor, if any, comply with all of the foregoing. In no case will
the safeguards of Contractor's data privacy and information security
program be less stringent than the safeguards used by MDHHS, and
Contractor must at all times comply with all applicable State IT
policies and-. standards, which are available to Contractor upon
request.
8

 A Letter of a summary of HBC’s cybersecurity incident from Attorney 3 of
the XX law firm received on 6/8/2022. This letter reported various
information already explained by CA 1 related to the computer system
being encrypted with ransomware and what the agency did thereafter. This
letter named the law firm, as listed above, being retained by the agency, as
well as the name of the third-party investigation firm (Firm T), completing
the comprehensive forensic investigation. This summary indicated that
“Immediately upon discovery of the event, HBC took the affected systems
offline and rebuilt its domain controller. Firm T “collected and reviewed
available forensic evidence from HBC’s network and monitored HBC’s
network via an advanced endpoint detection and response (“EDR”) tool,
Carbon Black, which was deployed on the servers within the environment.
The forensic investigation did not identify any evidence or signs of data
exfiltration, such as the creation of zip files, archiving or staging data, or the
presence or use of exfiltration tools or data transfer applications. However,
the forensic investigation did identify that compromised user credentials
were used to view certain files and folders on HBC’s network between
February 23, 2021, and July 16, 2021. Although there was no evidence that
information was exfiltrated or stolen.” This letter summary further indicated
that HBC has no evidence of any identity theft or fraud in connection with
this Incident. Additionally, that to mitigate the impact of the Incident, HBC
promptly executed a password re-set for all user accounts and
implemented multi-factor authentication for email use. As part of the
comprehensive response, HBC also notified the Federal Bureau of
Investigation (“FBI”) of this Incident and cooperated with its subsequent
investigation and data requests.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12213 Record Management.
An agency shall do all of the following with respect to
maintenance of required records:
(c) Store and maintain each record in a manner to ensure
confidentiality and to prevent unauthorized access.
9

ANALYSIS: The agency’s 2008 server was hacked and encrypted with
ransomware and certain children files were viewed or accessed.
Three-hundred-sixty-four individuals were identified as being
impacted by this incident; 65, individuals were, known to be
associated with MDHHS, with some being children. The
agency’s investigation of the security incident identified that
compromised user credentials were used to view certain files
and folders on HBC’s network between February 23, 2021, and
July 16, 2021.
There is insufficient data to conclude the agency’s electronic
files were not in a manner to ensure confidentiality and prevent
unauthorized use. The evidence showed the agency’s older
server system was hacked just as they were upgrading to a
greater 2016 cybersecurity system.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
Contract 4.31 e. State Data
Loss or Compromise of Data:
“In the event of any act, error, or omission, negligence,
misconduct, or a breach on the part of Contractor that
compromises or is suspected to compromise the security,
confidentiality, or integrity of State Data or the physical,
technical, administrative, or organizational safeguards put in
place by Contractor that relate to the protection of the security,
confidentiality, or integrity of State Data, Contractor must, as
applicable:
1)Notify MDHHS as soon as practicable but no later than 24
hours of becoming aware of such an occurrence.
10

ANALYSIS: The agency did not report the breach timely as required by its
MDHHS contracts. The contract standard does not indicate the
agency has to know for a fact what State data was breached.
It indicates that the compromise to the security, confidentiality,
or integrity of State Data or the physical, technical,
administrative, or organizational safeguards put in place by
Contractor, that relates to the protection of the security,
confidentiality, or integrity of State Data can be suspected. In
this incident when the agency became aware its system/ files
were encrypted with ransomware, a suspicious of compromised
data would be a reasonable conclusion; and the breach should
have reported prior to 1/7/2022. It was not.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency’s
current licensing status is recommended.
